Hello, new member here. I have been playing around with the Mathlib library, and I got stuck with this theorem

https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/3dd071bc2260b3cf9a71863d0dee1242fec41522/Mathlib/CategoryTheory/Category/RelCat.lean#L87

which characterizes isomorphisms in RelCat. Based on what I understand, this theorem as stated is not universe polymorphic. In particular, it uses Type rather than Type u. However, by simply replacing Type with Type u in the statement and proof, the theorem would become universe polymorphic.

Being a new user, I have two questions:

  1. Is the theorem secretly universe polymorphic, and I am just not seeing it?
  2. Where is the right place to ask about this? Because I think the new members chat is probably not the right place...
Indeed, Type should be replaced by Type u to make the statement universe polymorphic.
Since this is about the Mathlib library, I think #mathlib4 would be a good place for it; but if you think your question is really more about the underlying math, you could put it in #maths as well
Nick Mertes has marked this topic as resolved.
